I've never liked helping people purge their own nodes (except for usual clear reasons for reaping nodes). I've always been against reaping blank nodes or nodes marked as the author wanting it to be deleted when it has a reply. I'm more convinced of that now. If I see a blanked-out node or author-requested deletion that has a reply, I will vote "keep" and I won't unconsider it. If I see a reply to such a node marked as "reparent", I will vote "keep" and I won't move it. We should not be helping people rewrite history.

[Olecram] has a lot of options open and needs to adapt in a more useful manner (post anonymously, get a new ID and don't use it to yell at people in the chatterbox, grow up and stop yelling at people, just ask questions here and go elsewhere to yell at people, etc.). If "blanking" the node doesn't get it reaped (when it has replies), then [Olecram] will have to pick a new tactic.

This came up before but appears to have been purged from the wiki (I'm curious why). Let us not get carried away with the ability to rewrite history. Let us restrict our actions to being janitors and cleaning up messes made by technical goofs, not cleaning up peoples' words that they regret. Down that path lies madness (and people not thinking before they post cause they know that they can just blank it out and we'll make it appear as if they'd never said anything). If someone posts a node and then regrets it, then they can replace the node with a notice/apology. We need to encourage that over trying to reap the node.

Well, the DeCSS code was a different issue. A similar one, in some ways, but different from, in particular, a legal standpoint. Though I know that node went away, I'm still unclear as to how, or whose decision it was. No policy statement that I can recall was ever articulated on the topic; this, I think, should change. I would also like to see a policy decision (publically) made which covers cases like port scanners. Whatever that decision might be, I'm sure we'll all abide it.

Though I use the word 'never', my statement is not wholly unqualified. I do specify the opinions of a few editors... not a quorum, or even a lot. For that reason, I think my statement reasonable; and I think three is just too few in such a case. This is why I do not feel compelled to say 'almost'.

Editorial deletion is a great, almost unchecked power, and the fact that it has caused so little strife until now is to the credit of our editors. I feel that in this case it went awry, however, and I regretted my inability to cast an editorial keep vote, or (short of going deus ex machina to the database, which I am always loathe to do, and for which there was little time) to pause the process for discussion.

The present case disturbed me less than the sudden apprehension that we did not share the same underlying principles on editing; I'm glad that, on everything I feel is important, we agree, [footpad]. Not to say that my principles are the best ones, but a general consensus makes life far easier where the social structure is not rigid. If you over-reacted... then you did as we all do from time to time. Such is life.

I've recently made quite a few suggestions for changing the editorial experience (thanks for implementing some of the suggestions :). Lately I've been wondering if adding more automated messages to send is the way to go about it.

Rather than all the disjointed messages to people, and notes at the bottom of nodes, perhaps a log of actions taken for a node (approval, moving to a new section, reparenting, editing, consideration, unconsideration, and so on) would be useful. Everything could be automatically logged, with an option for the person to provide an explanation. Logging could of course optionally also send messages as well. I'd suggest that by default edits to the node be displayed below the node (much like our current paste-ins), with the complete log a click away.

I think this is probably a fair amount of work and not likely to happen soon, but it has some advantages. First, it means the burden of remembering what was done to a node doesn't fall upon the people who did it. It would also serve the function of reducing the fears of those who worry editors have no accountability. I think a fair amount of information that would go in the log is already stored in various ways in the database; this would group related information together.

kudra, 2002-06-06
I was recently making a number of suggestions to ar0n, and it got to the point that he recommended I make a list here to get other opinions (and probably to save himself some msgs). This is not to say that I'm not happy with the improvements to editor tools, such as ehomat and the 'edit' link in nre, but I still find myself repeating a lot of the same tasks several times daily and I think there's room for more automation, especially as the nodes that require editor assistance continue to increase.

  • An editor's version of ntc
    Right now, you have to click on a node in order to give it an editorial delete vote, or to unconsider it (assuming it doesn't have enough edit votes to show up in nre). I would like to see editorial delete and unconsider options that can be applied to a number of nodes at one time, much like the current ntc options. The delete would be useful for large numbers of blank nodes (there were at least 5 in ntc today), whereas the unconsider could be used for nodes which have too many keep votes to be deleted.
  • Automatic messaging box for unconsidered nodes
    I have recently started msging people when I unconsider their nodes due to a large number of keep votes. The message is generally: [id://1|a node you considered] has been unconsidered due to the number of keep votes. It should probably also contain a link to the consideration guidelines. I'd like the choice to send a message whenever I unconsider something (as I get with reparenting and editing). Update: consideration guidelines are at [id://92975|92974].
  • Editor's signature
    I paste in the same few lines every time I edit a node. I'd like to see a default signature (either one written by each editor, or a generic one) in a seperate text box below the node I'm editing, with a checkbox (by default selected) to include the signature. Putting it in the textbox allows me to fill in the reason, and perhaps the date, although it would be much nicer if the date were automagically supplied. Having the checkbox allows me to leave out the signature, as I generally do when the author considered the node her/himself.
  • Multiple tasks in the same form
    Editing currently involves many, many reloads. I'd like to see some of the tasks combined in to the same form. For example, when editing a node, the 'submit' button could also include an unconsider checkbox, and a message to the node author (with a radio button to enable/disable sending it). In this instance the preview button would ignore everything other than the message text, regardless of its values. Another example is in ehomat: there could be an option to unconsider the child node and message the author of the child node on the same screen as 'does this look right?' (naturally ignored if you opt for no).
  • Anon authors excluded from default message sending
    If the author is anon, it would be nice not to have the default message displayed after editing. I usually catch myself, but sometimes I try to message anon when I've edited a node.
I do hope that some of these will be implemented, because it would really reduce the amount of work for editors. Right now I rarely spend less than 15 minutes a day editing, and I only see the time increasing :(
